title: Inflammatory Myopathy (Dermatomyositis/Polymyositis)
icd10: ** G72.41 (Inclusion body myositis - note: excluded from this template scope but listed for differential)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of inflammatory myopathies including dermatomyositis, polymyositis, and immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy. Includes diagnosis, acute management, immunotherapy, interstitial lung disease (ILD) screening, malignancy screening, and disease-modifying therapy. Excludes inclusion body myositis (IBM -- separate plan), drug-induced myopathy, infectious myositis, and metabolic myopathies.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Neuromuscular specialist for diagnostic confirmation, antibody interpretation, and immunotherapy guidance
Rheumatology co-management for overlap connective tissue disease, shared immunotherapy decisions, and skin disease management
Pulmonology for ILD evaluation, PFT interpretation, and respiratory management (mandatory if anti-Jo-1, anti-MDA5, or any respiratory symptoms)
Dermatology for DM rash management, skin biopsy if needed, and photosensitivity counseling
Oncology referral for malignancy screening and management (mandatory if anti-TIF1-gamma positive or age >40 with new DM)
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation given dysphagia risk (cricopharyngeal and proximal esophageal involvement common in inflammatory myopathy)
Physical therapy for proximal weakness rehabilitation, fall prevention, and graded exercise program (avoid eccentric exercise during active inflammation)
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, energy conservation, and upper extremity function given proximal weakness
Cardiology if elevated troponin, arrhythmia, or anti-SRP antibody positive (myocarditis risk)
Gastroenterology for dysphagia evaluation (esophageal manometry, EGD) and malignancy screening (colonoscopy)
Gynecology for ovarian cancer screening in female DM patients (especially anti-TIF1-gamma positive)
Social work for disability evaluation, insurance navigation for biologic therapies, and community resources
Infusion center coordination for IVIG, rituximab, or cyclophosphamide infusion scheduling
Pain management if refractory myalgia or arthralgia not responding to standard analgesics and immunotherapy
Psychiatry/Psychology for adjustment to chronic illness, depression screening, and steroid-induced mood disturbance
Nutrition/Dietetics for dysphagia diet modification, weight management on steroids, and nutritional optimization for muscle recovery
Palliative care for severely refractory disease with significant symptom burden and goals of care discussion

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if worsening difficulty breathing or new shortness of breath (may indicate ILD progression or respiratory muscle failure)
Return to ED if worsening difficulty swallowing, choking on food or liquids, or new voice changes (aspiration risk)
Return to ED if dark brown or cola-colored urine (may indicate rhabdomyolysis requiring urgent IV fluids)
Return to ED if new chest pain or palpitations (may indicate myocarditis or cardiac involvement)
Report any new rash or worsening skin changes to neurology/rheumatology (may indicate disease flare or new DM diagnosis)
Do NOT stop prednisone or immunosuppressant abruptly (adrenal crisis risk; disease flare risk)
Monitor and report progressive difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chairs, reaching overhead, or lifting head from pillow (proximal weakness worsening)
Avoid sun exposure and use broad-spectrum SPF 50+ sunscreen daily for DM skin disease (UV light worsens DM rash)
Report any fever or signs of infection immediately to treating physician (immunosuppression increases infection risk)
Take medications as prescribed; bring complete medication list to ALL healthcare visits
Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments (CK monitoring and strength assessment are essential to guide treatment)
Do not drive if significant proximal weakness limits ability to safely operate vehicle pedals or steering
Use fall precautions including grab bars, non-slip mats, and assistive devices as recommended by PT/OT given proximal weakness
Rest before meals if dysphagia present; eat smaller, more frequent meals; sit upright for 30 min after eating
Report any new lump, unexplained weight loss, blood in stool/urine, or persistent pain (malignancy screening is important in myositis)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Graded exercise program supervised by physical therapist -- low-impact aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, stationary bike) is safe and beneficial even during active disease; avoid eccentric/high-resistance exercise during active inflammation
Strict sun protection for all DM patients: broad-spectrum SPF 50+ daily, photoprotective clothing, wide-brimmed hat, avoid peak UV hours (10am-4pm)
Smoking cessation as smoking worsens ILD and impairs immune function
Balanced high-protein diet to support muscle recovery (1.2-1.5 g/kg/day protein); adequate calcium and vitamin D intake for bone health on steroids
Low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention and blood pressure elevation on corticosteroids
Influenza vaccination (inactivated) annually; pneumococcal vaccination per schedule; avoid live vaccines during immunosuppression
Shingles vaccination (Shingrix -- non-live recombinant vaccine) if age >=50 or immunosuppressed
Complete all vaccinations before starting immunosuppression when possible (ideally 4-6 weeks before rituximab)
Annual dermatologic exam for skin cancer screening given immunosuppression and DM skin disease
Annual age-appropriate malignancy screening for 3-5 years after DM diagnosis (highest cancer risk in first 3 years)
Energy conservation techniques: prioritize tasks, use adaptive equipment, plan rest periods throughout the day
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards given proximal weakness and fall risk
Alcohol limitation as alcohol interacts with methotrexate (hepatotoxicity) and immunosuppressants
Adequate sleep (7-9 hours) to promote immune health and muscle recovery

differential.features: Age >50; insidious onset; distal weakness (finger flexors, wrist flexors, quadriceps); asymmetric; refractory to immunotherapy; CK mildly elevated or normal
differential.tests: Muscle biopsy (rimmed vacuoles, eosinophilic inclusions, congophilic amyloid deposits); anti-cN1A antibody; EMG (mixed myopathic + neurogenic pattern)

differential.features: Proximal weakness with fatigue; elevated CK (mild); hypothyroid symptoms (weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation); delayed relaxation of reflexes
differential.tests: TSH (elevated); free T4 (low); CK normalizes with thyroid replacement

differential.features: Temporal correlation with drug initiation; statin myopathy most common; steroid myopathy causes proximal weakness without CK elevation
differential.tests: Drug history; CK may or may not be elevated (statin); improvement after drug discontinuation; EMG may be normal or myopathic; biopsy shows type 2 fiber atrophy (steroid myopathy)

differential.features: Earlier onset (variable); family history; progressive without remission; specific pattern of weakness; no rash
differential.tests: Genetic testing; CK elevated; muscle biopsy (dystrophic changes, absent/reduced protein on immunostaining); no inflammation or perifascicular atrophy

differential.features: Fasciculations; upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski); mixed UMN/LMN pattern; bulbar onset may mimic dysphagia; no rash; no CK elevation or mild only
differential.tests: EMG (widespread active denervation, fasciculations); normal muscle enzymes or mildly elevated CK; no myositis antibodies

differential.features: Fatigable weakness (worse with repetitive use, improves with rest); ocular involvement (ptosis, diplopia); normal CK; intact reflexes
differential.tests: AChR/MuSK antibodies; RNS (decremental response); SFEMG (increased jitter); normal CK; ice pack test

differential.features: Proximal weakness with facilitation (improvement after brief exercise); autonomic dysfunction; often paraneoplastic (SCLC)
differential.tests: VGCC antibody; RNS (incremental response at high rate); CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Age >50; proximal pain/stiffness more than weakness; elevated ESR/CRP; rapid response to low-dose prednisone (15-20 mg); normal CK; normal strength on exam
differential.tests: ESR/CRP markedly elevated; CK normal; EMG normal; dramatic response to low-dose prednisone; PET/CT may show bursitis/synovitis

differential.features: Associated endocrine symptoms; steroid myopathy presents with proximal weakness but normal CK; insidious onset
differential.tests: Cortisol, ACTH, calcium, PTH; CK normal in steroid myopathy; EMG may be normal; biopsy shows type 2 fiber atrophy

differential.features: Exercise intolerance; second wind phenomenon (McArdle); ptosis and ophthalmoparesis (mitochondrial); infantile or late-onset forms (Pompe)
differential.tests: Acid alpha-glucosidase activity (Pompe); myophosphorylase activity (McArdle); lactate/pyruvate ratio; genetic testing; muscle biopsy (ragged red fibers, vacuoles)

differential.features: Acute onset with viral prodrome; self-limited in influenza; HIV/HTLV-1 chronic
differential.tests: Viral serology; self-limited course (influenza); HIV testing; biopsy if persistent

differential.features: Granulomatous myopathy; systemic involvement (lungs, skin, eyes, lymph nodes); elevated ACE level
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT (hilar lymphadenopathy); muscle biopsy (non-caseating granulomas); gallium scan or PET/CT

differential.features: Eosinophilia; travel/exposure history; periorbital edema (trichinosis); fever
Features of multiple autoimmune diseases; Raynaud phenomenon; sclerodactyly; sicca symptoms; malar rash
differential.tests: ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Scl-70, anti-U1 RNP, anti-SSA/SSB; specific overlap antibodies (anti-PM-Scl, anti-Ku)

monitoring.frequency: q24-48h inpatient during acute phase; q2-4 weeks outpatient during treatment; q3 months when stable
monitoring.action: If CK rising or not declining: reassess immunotherapy intensity; check compliance; consider refractory disease or alternative diagnosis

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; standardized manual muscle testing of proximal groups (deltoid, hip flexors, neck flexors)
monitoring.action: If worsening: increase immunotherapy; reassess diagnosis; consider biopsy if not done

monitoring.frequency: Baseline then q3-6 months; q1-2 months if ILD present or anti-MDA5/anti-Jo-1 positive
monitoring.action: If declining >10% FVC or >15% DLCO: escalate ILD treatment; pulmonology referral; repeat HRCT

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; repeat q6-12 months if ILD present; sooner if symptoms worsen
monitoring.action: If progressive: escalate immunotherapy (cyclophosphamide, rituximab, JAK inhibitor); consider lung transplant referral if refractory

monitoring.frequency: q6h during pulse steroids; daily during high-dose oral; HbA1c q3 months on chronic steroids
monitoring.action: Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent hyperglycemia; attempt steroid taper

monitoring.frequency: q2-4 weeks during immunosuppressant titration; then q4-8 weeks when stable
monitoring.action: Hold/reduce immunosuppressant if cytopenic; G-CSF if severe neutropenia; infection evaluation if febrile

monitoring.frequency: q2-4 weeks during methotrexate/azathioprine titration; then q8-12 weeks
monitoring.action: If hepatic transaminases rising (disproportionate to CK): hold offending agent; hepatology referral; consider alternative steroid-sparing agent

monitoring.frequency: q24h during rhabdomyolysis; q1-3 months on tacrolimus; q3 months otherwise
monitoring.action: If declining: aggressive hydration during rhabdomyolysis; dose-adjust nephrotoxic agents; nephrology referral
Adjust or avoid azathioprine based on TPMT status

monitoring.frequency: q1-2 weeks during titration; then q1-3 months
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment based on level and clinical response
Redose rituximab when B-cells recover and symptoms worsen

monitoring.frequency: q6 months if on rituximab or chronic immunosuppression
monitoring.action: IVIG replacement if symptomatic hypogammaglobulinemia with recurrent infections

monitoring.frequency: Daily if dysphagia present; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: NPO if aspiration risk; SLP reevaluation; may need NG tube or PEG

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if starting chronic steroids; repeat q2 years
Baseline; annual after 5 years (or 1 year if high risk)
monitoring.action: Discontinue HCQ if retinal toxicity detected

monitoring.frequency: At diagnosis; annually for 3-5 years after DM diagnosis; comprehensive if anti-TIF1-gamma positive
Baseline; repeat if symptoms; annually if anti-SRP positive
monitoring.action: Cardiology referral; cardiac MRI if troponin elevated

monitoring.frequency: Hourly during rhabdomyolysis; daily inpatient otherwise
monitoring.action: Aggressive IV hydration; consider bicarbonate drip; nephrology if oliguric

disposition.criteria: Mild myositis with preserved functional ability (able to rise from chair, climb stairs, lift arms overhead); stable CK and trending down; adequate oral intake and safe swallow; oral medications tolerated; no ILD or stable ILD; reliable outpatient follow-up within 1-2 weeks; understands return precautions

Moderate-severe proximal weakness (unable to rise from chair or climb stairs without assistance); CK >5000 or rising; new diagnosis requiring expedited workup including muscle biopsy; dysphagia requiring diet modification; ILD requiring monitoring; IVIG infusion; steroid initiation with monitoring needs

Rhabdomyolysis with CK >10,000 and myoglobinuria (renal failure risk); respiratory failure from ILD (especially anti-MDA5 rapidly progressive ILD); severe dysphagia with aspiration pneumonia; cardiac involvement (myocarditis, arrhythmia); hemodynamic instability during PLEX

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for PLEX not available on-site; need for muscle biopsy with neuromuscular pathology expertise; neuromuscular specialist not available; rapidly progressive ILD requiring advanced respiratory support; consideration for lung transplant evaluation
Significant proximal weakness limiting ADLs (unable to walk independently); able to participate in 3h/day therapy; medically stable; oral medications established; no active rhabdomyolysis
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care; severe deconditioning; chronic high-level care needs
